numbered_ace_sentences: 1. There is a major jump in admissions advantage when the parents' income rank reaches the 99th percentile.
2. The first jump in estimated admissions advantage begins around the 70th income percentile for legacy applicants.
3. The first jump in estimated admissions advantage begins around the 70th income percentile for non-legacy applicants.
4. Around the 50th income percentile, the admissions advantage for legacy students goes down.
5. Around the 50th income percentile, the admissions advantage for non-legacy students goes down.
6. Around the 80th income percentile, the admissions advantage for legacy students goes down.
7. Around the 80th income percentile, the admissions advantage for non-legacy students goes down.
8. I wonder what caused the drop in admissions advantage around the 50th income percentile for both groups.
9. I wonder what caused the drop in admissions advantage around the 80th income percentile for both groups.
10. I am a student in a high school.
11. Every year, students in my high school apply to many different colleges and universities.
12. It is interesting to see that a student's income can increase the chance that the student gets into a college.
13. It is tiresome to see that a student's income can increase the chance that the student gets into a college.
14. It is interesting to see that a student's legacy status can increase the chance that the student gets into a college.
15. It is tiresome to see that a student's legacy status can increase the chance that the student gets into a college.
16. It is sad that two students can have the same level of scores and resumes.
17. It is sad that a college can reject a student because of the student's income.
18. It is sad that a college can reject a student because of the student's legacy status.
19. A student cannot control the student's income.
20. A student cannot control the student's legacy status.
21. The headline is: Should legacies be the only ones to leave a legacy?
